div1.head: Military Orders for Paul Hamann and Alfred W. Covington, October 21, 1901
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 61 - 1901
Hamann - Covington

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 230. }

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA,
Havana, October 21, 1901.

1. Under authority of the Acting Secretary of War,
dated August 17, 1901, general prisoner Isaac Fullerton,
late private troop D, 10th Cavalry, is hereby transferred to
Fort Columbus, New York Harbor, to serve out the remain-
der of his sentence as published in paragraph 8, Special
Orders No. 107, current series, these Headquarters.

The commanding officer, Holguín, Cuba, will send the
prisoner, under proper guard, together with all papers relat-
ing to the prisoner, to Fort Columbus, New York Harbor,
so as to arrive there not later than November 15, 1901, to
be turned over to the commanding officer thereat.

Upon completion of this duty the guard will return to its
proper station.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

2. Private Frank Snodgrass, troop B, 10th Cavalry, hav-
ing reported at these Headquarters, in compliance with
paragraph 10, Special Orders No. 231, current series, Head-
quarters Department of the East, the Quartermaster's
Department will furnish him the necessary transportation
from this city to Holguin, Cuba, where upon arrival Private
Snodgrass will report to his troop commander for duty.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

3. 1st Lieutenant F. H. Gallup, Artillery Corps, is hereby
relieved from further duty at the Headquarters Artillery
Defenses of Havana, and will proceed to Columbia Barracks,
reporting to the commanding officer for duty.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

4. Private John F. Burleson, Hospital Corps, U. S. Army,
having completed the duty assigned him in paragraph 1,
Special Orders No. 76, current series, Post of Manzanillo,
the Quartermaster's Department will furnish him the
necessary transportation from this city to Manzanillo, Cuba.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

5. The commanding officer, Artillery Defenses of Havana,
is hereby authorized to transfer privates Paul Hamann and
Alfred W. Covington, 23d Company, Coast Artillery, now
under treatment in the hospital at that post, to the hospital
at Columbia Barracks, Cuba, when in the opinion of the
post surgeon such transfer can be effected with perfect
safety to the patients.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

6. Leave of absence for ten (10) days, with permission
to go beyond the limits of the Department, is hereby granted
to Captain L. S. McCormick, 7th Cavalry.

7. Paragraph 2, Special Orders No. 191, as amended by
paragraph 1, Special Orders No. 201, current series, these
Headquarters, directing the officers mentioned therein to
proceed to New York, so as to arrive there December 1,
1901, is, in compliance with telegraphic instructions from
the Adjutant General's Office, dated October 21, 1901,
further amended to read, so as to arrive at New York,
November 1, 1901, or as soon thereafter as practicable.
BY COMMAND OF BRIGADIER GENERAL WOOD:

H. L. SCOTT,
Captain 7th Cavalry,
Adjutant General.
